deIdi2b2.TEXT:
Record date: 2078-09-26
Date 09/26/2078 Surgery ADMISSION NOTE
PATIENT: Hendricks, Hannah
MRN: 75322175
Attending: Shea
CC: L foot pain
HPI: 52 y/o F with Hx of HTN, hyperlipidemia, PVD, s/p R fem-pop bypass and L fem-DP bypass, both in 2066. She was doing well until April 2078, when she presented with a non-healing ulcer and gangrene in her L third toe and subsequently underwent a redo L fem-anterior tibial bypass using R basilic and cephalic veins on 5/3/78. On 6/11/78 she had graft scanning, which indicated a widely patent left leg graft and ankle-brachial indices at that time were normal bilaterally. However, she presented on 9/17/78 c/o L foot pain. On physical exam, she was noted to have a very small pinhole ulcer over the plantar aspect of her left great toe. She now presents with increasing pain, “32” on scale 0-10 that is constant in nature, with occasional sharp spikes in intensity. She also confirms loss of sensation and motor strength in the L foot, but there is no paresthesia. She denies CP, SOB, N/V, flank pain, or any urinary Sx and has no history of cardiac disease.
PMH:
- diabetes type 1 since age 10
- PVD
- HTN
- hyperlipidemia
PSH:
- L fem-anterior tibial bypass - 5/3/78
- Right fem-pop bypass - 2066
- Left fem-DP bypass – 2066
MEDS:
- Atenolol 25mg PO QD
- Valsartan 160mg PO BID
- ASA 325mg PO QD
- Oxycodone 5-10mg PO Q3H PRN pain
- Vitamin C 500mg PO BID
- Folic Acid 1mg PO BID
- Colace 100mg PO BID
- Neurontin 300mg PO TID
ALL: Percocet - nausea
FH: Brother died of heart attack at 48, father had MI x3; no one else in the family has had either DM type I or PVD
SH:
Lives in Morehead, WI with her partner. Smoked for 3 years in her early 20's, but there is no recent EtOH/TOB/IVDU. Works as a Senior Manager of Broadcasting.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
VITALS 97.8 74 136/48 18 95%RA FSglucose 74
General – NAD, well appearing
Pulmonary – clear to auscultation bilaterally, with no crackles or wheezes appreciated
Cardiac – regular rate and rhythm; S1 and S2 normal; no murmurs, rubs or gallops;
Abdomen – soft, non-distended; non-tender without rebound and guarding
Extremity – Warm bilaterally; well-healed bypass incisions bilaterally; L foot erythematous, mildly edematous; no clubbing, cyanosis; ulcer on the L big toe and a small dermal hematoma on the L 5th toe; tissue loss of tip of 2nd and 3rd toes, tip of 3rd toe with blackened, necrotic tissue, no drainage
Pulses: Fem Pop DP PT
R 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+
L 2+ 2+ non-dopplerable non- dopplerable
Neurology – CN II-XII grossly intact, 5/5 motor strength and normal sensation bilaterally including L foot
Mental status – alert and oriented x 3
--
LABORATORIES:
Chem 7, CBC, coags, clot ordered
UA negative
--
EKG: Sinus; rate ~75; normal intervals; normal R wave progression; T wave inversion in V1; no ST segment changes; overall comparable to previous EKG
--
RADIOLOGICAL STUDIES:
CXR 09/26/2078: (Prelim) Lung fields clear, no effusions
09/26/78
Type: Arterial Ultrasound Tests
The following are the velocities in cm/s, proximal to distal:
COMMON FEMORAL 200
PROXIMAL ANASTOMOSIS 307
PROXIMAL GRAFT 84
PROXIMAL GRAFT 211
PROXIMAL GRAFT 318
PROXIMAL-MID 94
MID THIGH 26
DISTAL THIGH 13
PROX TO DISTAL ANASTOMOSIS 5
DISTAL ANASTOMOSIS 40
Brachial pressure=152 / Right ankle=141 abi=0.92 / Left ankle=30 (anterior tibial) abi=0.19
Date: 09/17/78
Type: Venous Ultrasound Tests
There is no evidence of thrombosis in either the right or left common femoral, superficial femoral and popliteal veins. There is no gross evidence of deep vein thrombosis in the left calf.
Date: 06/11/78
Type: Arterial Ultrasound Tests
right brachial pressure 168 mmHg left brachial pressure 169 mmhg
right dp 154 mmhg left dp 143 mmHg
right pt 156 mmHg left pt 151 mmHg
Patent arterial bypass graft with no evidence of hemodynamically significant stenosis.
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
52 y/o F with Hx of diabetes type I and PVD, s/p several bypasses, presenting with worsening L foot pain of two weeks duration. On physical exam, L foot is exquisitely tender and while it is warm to touch, it is erythematous and there is an ulcer on the plantar surface of the big toe. In addition, ABIs from today show L ankle ABI of 0.19. The etiology of her pain is an occlusion of the L fem-anterior tibial bypass vs. diabetic neuropathy, however, she has been taking neurontin without relief and the diabetic neuropathy is less likely.
- oxycodone for pain control, continue neurontin
- continue home atenolol, ASA, Valsartan
- NPO from midnight, pepcid
- check chem7, CBC, coags
- has an insulin pump
- angiography vs. angioplasty tomorrow
_____________
Hayden Shepherd
MANAMANA IV
01722
Patient seen and examined. Agree with medical student note above. Briefly, 52yF with DM I, HTN, hyperlipidemia s/p bilateral revascularization procedures for PVD presents with complaints of left foot pain limiting walking to several feet as well as with small ulcers on her toes. ABIs are very diminished on the left and graft scan shows elevated velocities at proximal anastomosis. She is admitted in anticipation of angiography in am.
N: Cont oxycodone, neurontin
CV: Cont home meds
Resp: F/u final CXR read
GI: Diabetic diet; NPO after MN
GU: D5 ½ NS @ 100 after MN; foley to be placed at 6AM
Heme: SQH
ID: No issues
Endo: Patient has insulin pump and knows to adjust this when she is NPO
Other: Consent for angiogram in chart
Discussed with Dr. Weller, vascular chief resident, who agrees with assessment and plan.
______________
Kathryn Brewer, MD
PGY 2
Pg 68283
